review_title: Draconian style of management and systems
pros: Nothing, truly awful place to work, can’t wait to leave.
cons: Overworked, underpaid and completely under appreciated. This company does not want to get with the times and does not allow for a wfh style, despite none of the office work being collaborative. Company is run via incompetent, old systems and account managers are given all the mess to clean up and maintain their organized chaos. Field partners are rude and lack coth or professional etiquette and nothing is said to them because the turnover rate is so high. Managers treat you more like their kids, instead of a peer and have serious power struggles, with pulling rank i.e. turn your camera on during meetings even internal, no wfh or flexibility and clocking when you get in or leave, despite all corporate office positions being salaried. Pay is also significantly low for the average for a role like this, which entails organizing their chaos and enduring abuse and overwork from corporate for stupid TODs, MAMS asking for menial tasks they can do theirselves and disrespectful field partners.

review_title: It's a hit or a miss
pros: 4 day work weeks. Decent pay if on a good route. Good Healthcare. Uniforms and boots supplied.
cons: There are the cooperate rules and the individual location rules. Cooperate puts a lot of stress on locations to meet quotas which leads location management to pushing shady sales tactics. Location I worked never had enough product on hand and was told to make it work. Told to never credit off invoice unless customer noticed. A lot of adding products to invoices under the discretion of free one week and banking on customer forgetting was on invoice for future charges. This is just the tip of the iceberg. Many more examples exist. I'd suggest all customers review all products and services on invoice are being serviced correctly. Some locations follow all cooperate rules but like any company there are individual locations that are shady. One phrase I hated was "you didn't just hear this from me, but" and then tells you do do shady things. Like HR telling me to alter dates on a doctor's note to return back to work sooner.

review_title: A Nice Sales Culture - A Mediocre Service
job_title: Uniform Sales Representative in Calgary, AB
pros: Commission is decently generous and there are a lot of leads that are sent your way once you win a territory.
cons: Often times you are feeling like you are lying when saying your service is better than the competition... Some territories are burnt to the ground based on previously lost accounts that were upset over price increases, sub par service, ect. The amount of work a sales person is expected to do to ensure the account is installed correctly is a massive headache. nearly all targets are in 5 year contract with our competition and even if you win their business it can take years before you received the commission for installing the account. Garments can take up to 6 months to receive the order so (usually around 6 weeks) -- your account cant be installed until the garments are received. Everything you need to do to install an account is a headache that takes a LONG time to accomplish.

review_title: Very old fashioned department but hours are hard to beat
pros: -Hours are extended during the close process but are very reasonable the rest of the year. I rarely work over 40 hours during non-close weeks, so that is a huge positive. -Many co-workers who have been at the company 10+ years, know a lot about the company and are willing to help answer questions. -well documented processes -The CFO, Mike Hansen, knows everyone by name -Work from home one day a week (this is up from no work from home) -Executive leadership (CEO/CFO) stresses “positive discontent” meaning if you don’t like how a process is done or think it could be smoother, you can suggest it.
cons: -Strict on one day working from home, no exceptions. There is no additional flexibility to work from home -Having to give reasons why you need to work from home to give to management while other groups within the accounting department do not. -Management has shown inconsistency in its’ ability to adapt to working-from-home for their teams, they make work from home a bigger deal than it should be for their members -Management isn’t willing to “get their hands dirty,” to take 5 minutes and look into things themselves. Asking repeatedly the same questions (and accepting the original answer) and not taking time for their own self review -The ability to make changes to processes is really on a team-by-team basis by division leaders (controller level, etc.) for positive discontent. My teams’ leaders do not listen to these suggestions at all. -Due to many team members being at the company for so long, some are highly resistant to change. In order to even make a small change, there can be A LOT of resistance. -There just seems to be a general fear and distrust of technology in management. Instead of a "trust but verify approach" to changes, its just ignored. -Division leaders’ continually stress speed in close processes while requiring individuals to perform highly manual processes. Management has not invested in automation at all which causes things to be slow. Basic investment would achieve the speed concept. -Certain processes are very antiquated and should be more streamlined but management is not interested. -Professional attire is required at all times, I don’t mind this but some may.

pros: Cintas provides products and services that are constantly in demand, and essential to most businesses. It’s a relatively easy sale.
cons: I work in recruiting for the entry level Outside Sales reps, Sales Trainees, Interns, Key Account Managers, and more. I recruit for all types of sales roles. What I have learned compared to the other companies I have worked with in the past is really shocking. There seems to be either no required training on employment and hiring laws, or the management staff just completely disregards any information they do receive, because I have had managers tell me directly “we’ll pass on this candidate, they are too old and outside our candidate profile”. They do not want to hire someone who has more than a few years of experience. I have had really quality candidates get dismissed because they have 10-15 years of experience. Beside the age discrimination, Cintas offers a $40-43k base which is laughably low in certain areas of the nation. Sure there are commissions, but your base needs to be able to cover your cost of living and for the majority of independent people looking for work this is a minimum of $10,000 below requirement. Cintas also insists on a long, ineffective recruiting process, for no good reason. There are 7 interview steps, including the application itself, also including a full day field ride along which most people currently employed have a hard time scheduling. They make candidates jump through these hoops, for what? To be fired after 6-12 months when they aren’t a president club rep? And why do you think candidates should jump through these hoops, when other sales companies are paying more in a base, more commission, car packages, company credit cards, better health benefits, and more. What makes you so special that you deem 7 interview steps necessary?

pros: The company culture is great and consistent. It's nice to work for a company where individual employees' motives are aligned to the company's goals, and not their own. Compensation is great, especially if you come in as an external applicant. Benefits are great, well-priced and comprehensive. They heavily invest in the most important and impactful ones (retirement, health/eye/vision plans), rather than underinvest in a broader variety of "fun" benefits that don't necessarily impact everyone.
cons:
The company does have a stigma that it can be too conservative or too old-school, but IT IS evolving quickly. Thelayer of leadership right below executive management is really pushing to modernize the workplace and align it with current expectations and recruiting/retention trends. It's not an overnight process, however. But the focus is there! 

Also, depending on the department you enter the company through, internal transfers can feel underpaid because of hiring ranges for internal applicants compared to external candidates. It's not always the case, but it does happen.

review_title: a few pros but a very stressful job
job_title: Service Sales Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: pay is not bad. and you usually get a compressed work week.
cons:
Training is focused on handling customer objections (there is a lot of them because of how questionable a lot of policies are) 
there is no real set pricing structure so you can be left with 2 customers paying vastly different prices for the same product and services. 
Service "agreements" (they dont like to use the word contract because it sounds negative) are set at 60 months. That is right, if you are a new business starting up, which a lot are, you are locked in for the next 5 years, and they tell you you can cancel at anytime, but in reality the wording of the agreement is you can cancel at anytime "if we are not able to change why you are unhappy", so usually your left with a hefty buyout. 
there are loaders that load your stuff for you the next day, but routinely would provide you with not enough product, the wrong product, or product that smelled. Even if you catch the errors in the morning before you leave (usually around 5am-5:30am) you can still be caught having to run the product out on your own time, in your own vehicle either after you are done your day (maybe around 3 or 4pm) or the next day when you have another full day.

KPI's are very unrealistic and a lot of times, out of your control anyways. Net adds fluctuates with the seasons, everyone goes up in the fall and down in the spring, but they still track your success based on that. 

And winters, at least in facility services in winter climates, really suck. Nothing like carrying 4 3x10 mats through an unpaved patch of sidewalk and falling. 

Oh and none of the service reps are ever happy here. It was always funny to get back from your day and see all the office staff laughing and eating food, while all the service reps looked miserable.

pros: 4 day work week, if you can afford to live on the below average salary without working your “extra day”
cons:
-Management is almost non existent. They are managers in title only. They offer NO support, no customer engagement, and most of them have never even ran a route. 
-The “HR” people might as well not work there, they don’t answer any questions or handle any employee issues. They just tell you to call the “hotline” which doesn’t have anyone that speaks understandable English.
-The pay structure is a joke. The more you add to your route (and the hours you work) the less you make. If you want to make more than 35 grand a year, you have to be shady and add things to your customers invoice or increase their already high prices on the things they are renting.
-The plant is a joke. They lose uniforms. Load wet smelly mats on your truck, and never load the right amount of products so you’re forced to run “specials” almost everyday to the area that you were in the day before. 
-They claim to be a safe company but driver safety isn’t even thought about unless some corporate suit visits the plant.
-They are anti union and violate labor laws daily. They tell employees not to discuss their wages; they fire people who even mention the union; and the managers spend more time talking about how a new female employee looks than doing their actual jobs.

This is specifically for the location 14K. Which I hear the location 180 down the street is a lot better. But as far as 14k, they do not have any desire to move you up. Being an SSR is about the most dead end job you can have. I was one that they promised the world, start here and move up. But you don't.

I was trying to get into the outside sales and had the world promised to me, just to be overlooked the entire time I was there. Didn't matter I have a bachelors degree, didn't matter I killed it on my route, didn't matter I told every manager, supervisor, and our GM that I want to move up it sales. When it came to promotion, it just was never there. They hire outside every time.

The SSR position is draining and exploited. Also its very telling when you have a Supervisor that has been there for over 30 years step down because it was better to be an SSR than a Supervisor.

pros:
Many friendly people
Vehicle package if car is less than 10 years old
cons:
Compensation plan is largely based on a bonus structure-- but the interviewers are wary about explaining how that works prior. They will tell you that 140-160k is attainable... however I knew no one hitting near that number and you really have to break your back to get near six figures at all.

Most reps were making a considerable amount less than the positions they had left for Cintas.

Your base pay is around 40k with a vehicle package included in that number.

Service and Sales are pitted against each other from the start. Once route drivers hit a volume threshold on their route they do not want you to sell anymore accounts because the amount of commission they receive drops.

No one will take the time to thoroughly review the comp plan with you- you're left wondering why you made more on certain accounts than others.

Management Trainees are coddled and given more leeway than sales reps.

Micromanagement and management does not respect employees boundaries

Pass off initiatives and parts of the sales managers responsibilities to captains- if your captain is not very involved with the team then goodluck. No extra compensation for taking a champion or captain role- and no guarantee of advancement. I saw an individual who had been with the company over 10 years be told to "not even bother applying" when a promotion opportunity opened up.

Sales rules are not followed-constant clash between uniform and facilities service reps selling accounts the other thought they should have.

Toxic positivity funnels through management from the top down.
They are unwilling to address team issues or innapropriate/ unprofessional behavior. You will be told that you are being negative if you do not ignore/ brush off problems.

Any issues with accounts will be blamed on the sales rep, despite the fact that many locations have minimal installers/ new account coordinators.

Good 'ol boys mentality

Culture was terrible at the branch level

review_title: Meh…not what I had hoped it would be
job_title: Facility Services Sales Representative in Milford, OH
pros:
Well known company that many customers have heard of before + top in their industry. Benefits were good, gas and vehicle insurance was paid for along with a small monthly amount for maintenance, phone bills, and car allowance. Autonomous - make your own schedule to build your sales pipeline. 

There is no better feeling then cold prospecting someone from beginning to close as a sales representative. It is a huge confidence booster! Also - clients typically gave you respect when you wore a suit each day!
cons:
Old school company (shirt and tie), seems to be stuck in the 90s sometimes…I’m pretty sure they just as of 2022 allowed men to grow beards. Technology is lacking severely (the tablets/were terrible to deal with at times.) The team was in competition with one another even though everyone is nice to your face in person (management pits reps, especially those in training, against one another.) Long training period, plus they make promises during onboarding that a territory will be given to you but that is not always the case (even if your sales numbers are consistent.)

Overall the experience was not what I had hoped it would be. The commission was not that great compared to what I was promised during the interview process or other sales organizations in Cincinnati. The base pay was sad considering you are an outside sales representative and the face of the organization. The sales pit at my location consisted of a boys club but that was starting to change thank goodness. My manager never went out on route with me once in the year+ that I had worked for him and would consistently cancel my 1v1’s.

Lastly - this is a very “drink the Kool-aid” company. Many people come straight out of college (management trainees) and work their whole career for Cintas, not knowing what else is out there. Management puts fear tactics in place that “the grass isn’t always greener”, and dangle carrots to naive employees (management trainees) that don’t know any better.

review_title: Great Colleagues, Stale Culture and Outdated Practices
pros: I had the pleasure of working with some great co-workers, colleagues, and managers in the specific division I worked in. Our specific office also tried its best to bring the culture to the 21st century, but could only go so far.
cons:
Culture, IT infrastructure, offices practices, and procedures are all outdated. When you walk into the headquarters of Mason, OH, prepare for an incredibly stale and 1990's corporate environment with the "business professional" dress code (suits and ties on men, blazers on women), old tan cubicles, and dry personalities. Luckily I was in the Chicago office where things tended to a LITTLE more casual, but always seemed as if our office was pushing the limits of being able to take the workplace to the 21st century. 

Working from home was basically unheard of, and IT was not prepared during the pandemic to let employees work remotely properly. They also force you to use Internet Explorer as your main browser.

Egos also tend to run rampant in some departments/roles.

This is definitely a "sip the kool-aid" type of company where employees get sucked in to thinking Cintas is the greatest because they're comfortable in their role and get handed these shiny "awards" for their hard work that are completely irrelevant to anywhere outside of the company.

job_title: Service Sales Representative in Brooklyn, NY
pros: People at the location were great for the most part. Everyone extremely friendly.
cons: So many TOD videos to watch for a job that is extremely easy. Most of the SSR’s just stuff cabinets so if you don’t care about morals which a lot of sales reps don’t in general, it’s a good shot to make a lot of money. PTO has to get taken regardless of if the office is closed due to a snow storm which makes no sense what so ever. Daily presentations and video conferences about common sense information. The intro test is in depth and I was required to know 30 names of people first and last and what they do despite never meeting them and having a call directory sheet in the van. Promotions require you to take on more responsibility for no pay incentive which is not ideal. For instance in order to get a promotion to a service manager position, you need to become a captain and likely will have to head one of their many committees, sometimes this means not starting your day until 10am which means loads of traffic. This job requires a big headache with inventory and driving the Van (especially in populated areas). Last Con and probably the biggest, certainly the main reason I resigned was the “SSR college program” at 6 months in you are forced to take this online class where you have to attend a class once a week 4 hours a class for 6 months, and you are expected to run route after the class. If you have a degree it’s probably not for you… I would avoid if possible but if you are in a bind, give it a shot it might pay off down the road, the people there really are nice, it’s just the company that’s a bit weird with certain things.

job_title: Sales Management Trainee in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good salary, great Job stability, room to make mistakes, great insurance.
cons: Company is handling the pandemic horribly- everyone still working full time in office when they could easily work from home given the resources to. Current policy is that if you get Covid you must stay home and quarantine for 14 days with no pay or use up all your pto. This has encouraged many people to end up coming into work even if they have symptoms and our office has had well over 15 cases now but nothing has changed. Total lack of direction from management towards trainees and spent several hours each day sitting around doing nothing during my first few months. Feels more like a terrible internship than management program. Company is extremely outdated both in culture and technology and doesn’t seem to have any competitive advantage other than their size. For how much they claim to be “family- oriented” they really don’t seem to care much about their employees.

review_title: Worst job I ever had, including high school fast food jobs
pros: Sales training is excellent. Very few companies offer equal training in handling objections, closing strategy, etc. Job security is decent. If you have a bad month, you have several chances before your job is threatened. Decent benefits. Good healthcare (at least at the time) and PTO. The car package doesn't count as a good benefit because it doesn't fully compensate for wear and tear imo.
cons: What I saw as extremely shady practices and toxic culture. I was there before the pandemic, VERY high turnover. Drivers and sales were incentivized to sneakily add volume to invoices to inflate numbers and adjust invoices later. This led to very angry customers constantly. I haven't worked there in 3 years and I still get calls (on my personal phone, they didn't give you a work phone, lol) on a monthly basis with people desperate to find someone to fix billing problems because sales and service people dodge them or blow it off. Sales managers awarded reps they liked by giving them hot leads and call-ins, rarely giving any to other reps. Management beyond local level had a very "look the other way" attitude towards the shenanigans. Very back-slappy, locker room, in-group/out-group culture in sales. Felt like high school with 25-40-year-olds, except high school was way better. Company brags about "Spartan attitude" which is weak PR lingo for being cheap. You had to use personal car and phone and get modest compensation for them. If your car didn't meet certain requirements, they made you buy a new one. Very stingy about rep expenses like treats for customers or office supplies. They were also very slow to update processes. In the 2010s they were using computer programs developed in the 80s or 90s--think black screen and green letters, etc. They focused on recruiting directly from college or bottom level sales, maybe because those recruits don't know better. Try a higher level sales job and it's like night and day. If you do Cintas, stay a year or two for the good experience and training, and use it as a stepping stone to anything better.

job_title: Service Sales Representative in Houston, TX

cons: Your base pay is 16k. Even if you hit all your goals the base pay raise isn’t even enough to offset inflation. Get real and actually pay your employees better. You were expected to grow your route even during covid when many businesses were closed. They want you to push a new item to your customers every month. At the end of the day they’re not the most ethical company even though they tell you all the time ethics are the most important aspect of the business. At the end of the day they don’t care about their loyal customers and just see them as a dollar sign. Some people don’t get promoted bc upper management doesn’t want to lose their top tier SSRs

job_title: Several Different Positions in Mason, OH
pros: Some room for growth, competitive corporate culture, ok benefits.
cons: In my opinion, Their number one priority is their shareholders, and not their customers nor employees. In April of 2020, as their business slowed down for a single quarter due to a pandemic that they knew was occurring since Jan, they laid of appx 10-15% of their labor, which in my opinion was to keep EPS high. They also sue their customers for ridiculous contract breaches if they cancel their rental service based off a legal agreement no average person would understand in my opinion. They underpay their production and operations employees. They do not invest in R&D and are decades behind in operational infrastructure and technology. They have very little organic growth and rely heavily on acquisitions and investing in PR/their brand to show growth year after year. Customers they gain through acqustions, Cintas attempts to raise their prices on same services. They have offshored manufactoring overseas to reduce costs too. There are so many Cons with this company, I could name serveral more. I'm disgusted with myself for staying with such an unethical company for as long as I did.

Serious lack of organization, lack of accountability, archaic internal systems, sales and service are supposed to “work together” but doesn’t work that way. 

Training is almost nonexistent and expectations are high, which is part of the reason they have such high turnover.  

This happened to myself as well, but I have seen leadership lie to new hires about the sales roles and seriously over promising results.  I took a $15k pay cut moving to this company and constantly told I was doing a great job, when they told me I would easily make $15k more; to me a $30k swing the other way is very misleading to just get someone to join the team.

During the pandemic directors stated we could not bring back furloughed people because we couldn’t financially handle it.  Meanwhile production and service teams struggle due to understaffing, and not 3 weeks later the same directors announce they had the best financial quarter ever!  Not to mention zero pay raises because of COVID but leadership still got their bonuses.  Great tactics
